verb.description: (in Christian belief) be condemned by God to suffer eternal punishment in hell.
Condemn, especially by the public expression of disapproval.
examples: intellectuals whom he damns as rigid doctrinaire idealists

adjective.description: Used for emphasis, especially to express anger or frustration.

phrases: Strategy be damned because we do not have secret proceedings in this country.
However, there are times when I want to be able to enter a bar and have a highball and a ciggy, health concerns be damned.
They'll look for some way to use the power of the state to their advantage, the truth be damned.
We all know, directly or otherwise, how possible is it to get a great nightlife in the city and restrictions be damned.
origin: Middle English: from Old French dam(p)ner, from Latin dam(p)nare inflict loss on, from damnum loss, damage.
